title.value: Inertia-based indices to determine the number of clusters in K-means: an experimental evaluation
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote:
Inertia-based indices to determine the
number of clusters in K-means: an
experimental evaluation

extractions.description: This paper provides an in-depth experimental evaluation of various inertia-based indices for determining the number of clusters in K-means clustering. It compares these indices with an objective to identify the best performers among them.

type.justification: The paper involves experimental evaluations and comparisons of different indices for K-means clustering.
type.quote:
This paper gives an experimentally supported review and comparison of several indices based
on the conventional K-means inertia criterion for determining the number of clusters.

name.justification: The paper focuses on K-means clustering, which is a method widely used in machine learning.
name.quote: K-means clustering is the most popular method in multivariate data sciences, especially in machine learning, data mining, and quantitative psychology.

name.justification: The study revolves around K-means clustering and methods to determine the optimal number of clusters using inertia-based indices.
name.quote: This paper computationally explores a popular approach for choosing the right number of clusters, K, in K-means clustering.

name.justification: A significant portion of the paper discusses the K-means algorithm, its evaluation, and the experimentation with different cluster number determination indices.
name.quote: K-means clustering is the most popular method in multivariate data sciences, especially in machine learning.

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not claim to have contributed a new version of the K-means algorithm but discusses the existing method.
is_contributed.quote: K-means clustering is the most popular method in multivariate data sciences, especially in machine learning.

is_executed.justification: The K-means algorithm is used in the experiments conducted in the study.
is_executed.quote: In our experiments, we use both real-world and synthetic datasets.

is_compared.justification: The K-means algorithm is compared with other indices in terms of determining the number of clusters.
is_compared.quote: This paper gives an experimentally supported review and comparison of several indices based on the conventional K-means inertia criterion for determining the number of clusters.

referenced_paper_title.justification: John A Hartigan's work on clustering algorithms is referenced in the context of examining K-means clustering methods.
referenced_paper_title.quote: John A Hartigan. Clustering algorithms. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., 1975.

name.justification: Random Swap is mentioned as a variant of the K-means algorithm used in the study.
name.quote: In this study, we also use a version of K-means with random 'mutations', allegedly helping to reach a deeper minimum of the criterion in (1). This version, referred to as Random Swap by [14], sometimes randomly changes one of the centers for one of the entities.

is_contributed.justification: The Random Swap algorithm is mentioned as an existing variant, not a contribution of the paper.

is_executed.justification: Random Swap is employed in the experiments conducted in the study.
is_executed.quote: In this study, we also use a version of K-means with random 'mutations'

is_compared.justification: Random Swap is compared with standard K-means in the study.
is_compared.quote: The Random Swap algorithm on top of K-means has hardly inflicted any changes in the results.

referenced_paper_title.value: Randomised local search algorithm for the clustering problem
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Random Swap variant of K-means is derived from this referenced work.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Pasi Fränti and Juha Kivijärvi. Randomised local search algorithm for the clustering problem.

name.justification: The K-means++ algorithm is discussed as an initialization method for the K-means algorithm.
name.quote: One option consists of the use of the very popular K-means++ algorithm.

is_contributed.justification: K-means++ is not a new contribution but rather an established variant explored in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: One option consists of the use of the very popular K-means++ algorithm.

is_executed.justification: The K-means++ algorithm is used in experiments for initialization purposes.
is_executed.quote: FIGURE 1... each of them obtained after carrying out the K-means++ initialization.

is_compared.justification: K-means++ is compared with other initialization methods for K-means.
is_compared.quote: According to this approach, the first center is a randomly chosen entity.

referenced_paper_title.value: k-means++: the advantages of careful seeding
referenced_paper_title.justification: K-means++ is referred to with this title when discussing initialization methods.
referenced_paper_title.quote: D. Arthur and S. Vassilvitskii. k-means++: the advantages of careful seeding.

name.justification: Iris is one of the datasets used in the experiments conducted in the paper.
name.quote: Minimum values of inertia D(K) ... on the popular Iris data set from the Irvine Repository.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Iris dataset is part of the UCI machine learning repository, which hosts it.

name.justification: The E.coli dataset is mentioned as one of the datasets used for evaluation in the study.
name.quote: Tables 5 and 6 report, respectively, the ARI and MARE values for eight of the eleven Irvine repository datasets considered in our study... E-coli.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The E.coli dataset is part of the UCI machine learning repository, which is cited in this context.

name.justification: Optical Digits is explicitly listed as one of the datasets used for experimentation in the paper.
name.quote: Tables 5 and 6 report, respectively, the ARI and MARE values for eight of the eleven Irvine repository datasets considered in our study... Optical Digits.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Optical Digits dataset is part of the UCI machine learning repository.

name.justification: The Zoo dataset is cited as one of the UCI datasets used for experimenting with cluster validity indices.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Zoo dataset is part of the UCI machine learning repository, referenced in the paper.
